$d.$ If $C$ is a curve, then. $\begin{array}{r}{\bar{q}(\bar{C})=\bar{p}_{g}(\bar{C}),}\end{array}$ which is denoted by $\bar{g}(C)$ . Let $\bar{C}$ be a nonsingular complete curve with $g=g(C)$ ,and let $D$ be $p_{0}+\cdots+p_{t}$ on $\overline{C}$ suchthat $c=c D$ . Then 
$$
\bar{g}(C)=l(K(\bar{C})+D)=1-g+2g-2+t+1-l(-D).
$$
If $D\neq0$ i.e., if $C$ is not complete, then $\bar{g}(\bar{C})=g+t.$ Thus 
$$
\bar{g}(C)=0\Leftrightarrow g=t=0\Leftrightarrow C\cong\mathbf{A}_{k}^{1}\Leftrightarrow\bar{\kappa}(C)=-\infty.
$$
Furthermore, if $\bar{g}(C)=1$ , then $g=1,t=0$ or $g=0,t=1$ . If $q=1$ , one has $\bar{P}_{2}(C)=2(t+1)$ .Hence, 
$$
\tilde{g}(C)=\bar{P}_{2}(C)=1\Leftrightarrow g=0,t=1\Leftrightarrow C\cong G_{m}\Leftrightarrow\bar{\kappa}(C)=0.
$$
Here, $G_{m}$ denotes $\operatorname{Spec}k[\mathsf{X},\mathsf{X}^{-1}]_{:}$ called the 1-dimensional algebraic torus over $k$ . Thus, one obtains the next table.

EXAMPLE 11.4. Let $F$ be a nonconstant polynomial in n variables $X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}$ $X_{n}$ .If $R$ is the integral closure of $k[F]$ in $k(\mathsf X_{1},\ldots,\mathsf X_{n})$ then $R=k[\psi]$ for some polynomial $\frac{l}{l}$ and $F$ can be written as a polynomial in $\frac{l}{f}$ . In particular, $k(\mathsf{X}_{1},\ldots,\mathsf{X}_{n})/k(\psi)\mathrm{i}$ s an algebraically closed extension of fields. 

This can be easily shown as follows: $F$ determines a dominating mor. phism $f$ from $A_{k}^{n}$ to $A_{k}^{1}=C$ . Then one has the Stein factorization of $f^{-}$ in the form: $\mathbf{A}_{k}^{n}\rightarrow\mathrm{Spec}\vec{R}\rightarrow\vec{C}.$ Spec $R$ is a nonsingular affine curve and $\bar{g}(\mathrm{Spec~}R)\leq\bar{q}(\mathrm{A}_{k}^{n})=0$ by Proposition 11.3.(i). Thus $\bar{g}(\bar{\bf S}\mathrm{pec}R)=0.$ which implies Spec $R\cong\mathbf{A}_{k}^{1}$ ; hence $R=k[\psi]$ 
e. Proposition 11.5. Let $V_{0}$ be an open subset of $12$ nonsingular variety $V^{\prime}$ such that codim $(V_{1}^{1},V_{10}^{2})=2$ Then $\begin{array}{r}{\bar{P}_{M}(V_{0})=\bar{P}_{M}(V)f o r a l l M.}\end{array}$ 
PROOF. Let $j:V_{0}^{\prime}\to V^{\prime}$ be the inclusion map. Take smooth completions $\bar{V}_{0}$ and $\overline{b^{\overline{{r}}}}$ of $V_{0}$ and $\mathbf{\boldsymbol{\mathbf{\bar{y}}}}^{F}$ with smooth boundaries $D_{0}$ and $D$ , respectively, such that $j$ defines a morphism μ $\iota\colon\overline{{V}}_{0}\to\overline{{V}}$ .Let $F$ be the closure of $F_{1}^{\prime}F_{0}^{\prime}$ in $\bar{V}$ Then codim $(F)\geq2$ and so by Lemma 2.32 one has 
$$
\Gamma(\bar{V}\backslash F,\Omega(\log D)^{M})=\Gamma(\bar{V},\Omega(\log D)^{M})=T_{M}(V).
$$
Since $\mu|_{\overline{{V}}_{0}\backslash\mu^{-1}(F)}:\bar{V}_{0}\backslash\mu^{-1}(F){\rightarrow\bar{V}}\backslash F $ is a proper birational morphism, $k^{\frac{3}{4}}$ gives rise to an isomorphism: 
$$
\Gamma(\vec{V}\backslash F,\Omega(\log D)^{M})\cong\Gamma(\vec{V}_{0}\backslash\mu^{-1}(F),\Omega(\log D)^{M}).
$$
However, since $\Gamma(\bar{V}_{0}\backslash\mu^{-1}(F),\Omega(\log D_{0})^{M})\supseteq\Gamma(\bar{V}_{0},\Omega(\log D_{0})^{M})=T_{M}(V_{0}),$ one has $\bar{P}_{M}(V)\geq\bar{P}_{M}(V_{0})$ and hence $\bar{P}_{M}(V)=\bar{P}_{M}(V_{0})$ by  Proposition 11.4.(ii). 口 
Theorem 11.3.. $L e t\mu$ and W be varieties with dim $V=n$ and dim $\mathbf{\Psi}^{\mathrm{~\tiny~\sharp~\sharp~=~\gamma~}^{\mathrm{~\tiny~\sharp~}}}$ Then ${\mathrm{i}}(V\times W)={\bar{q}}(V)+{\bar{q}}(W),{\bar{P}}_{m}(V\times W)={\bar{P}}_{m}(V)\cdot{\bar{P}}_{m}(W)$ for all $m\geq1.$ and $\bar{\hat{\epsilon}}(V\times W)=\bar{\hat{\kappa}}(V)+\bar{\hat{\kappa}}(W).$ 
PRoor.Wecan assume that both $\vec{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}^{r}$ and $\mu^{F}$ are nonsingular. As usual, take smooth completions $\overline{b^{\frac{y}{c}}}$ and $\sqrt{f^{\bar{f}}}$ of $\vec{\boldsymbol{\mu}}^{r}$ and $\mu^{y}$ with smooth boundaries $D$ and $B_{i}$ respectively. Then $\mathfrak{D}=\bar{V}\times B+D\times\bar{W}$ has only simple normal crossings and $\bar{Z}=V^{\bar{\bar{\tau}}}\times W$ is a smooth completion of $\gamma\times\sqrt{16}$ with smooth boundary $53$ : Letting $p\colon\bar{V}\times\bar{W}\to\bar{V}$ and $q\colon\bar{V}\times\bar{W}\to\bar{W}$ be projections, one has $\Omega_{\overline{{{Z}}}}^{1}(\log\mathfrak{D})=p^{\ast}(\Omega_{V}^{1}(\log D))\oplus q^{\ast}(\Omega_{\overline{{{W}}}}^{1}(\log B))$ and so $\Omega_{Z}^{n+r}(\log\mathfrak{D})=p^{*}(\Omega_{V}^{n}(\log$ $D))\bigotimes_{\vec{q}}*(\Omega_{\mathtt{W}}^{r}(\log B))$ . Therefore, 
$$
\begin{array}{r l}&{\bar{q}(V\times W)=\dim_{k}\Gamma(\bar{Z},\Omega_{\bar{z}}^{\bot}(\log\mathfrak{D}))}\ &{\qquad=\dim_{k}\Gamma(\bar{V},\Omega_{\bar{\nu}}^{\bot}(\log D))+\dim_{k}\Gamma(\bar{W},\Omega_{\bar{w}}^{\bot}(\log B))}\ &{\qquad=\bar{q}(V)+\bar{q}(\bar{W}).}\end{array}
$$
